description.text:
For Christmas, I made this little round box and gave to friends and family. The idea is to store all those little things that get lost in drawers or cans or wherever. So, folks I gave these to put buttons, or earrings or earring backs, baby teeth (or puppy teeth in my case-Ha!), or screws for your glassâs, or seeds from the garden, or small broken pieces they swear they will glue back on to that piece of furniture or pottery and so on. Only limits are size and your imagination. Then use the supplied index to list what is in each round box. Great fun for organization. To make, create 20 round boxes, put them into a 5 X 5 X 1 (inches) box, put 1 inch diameter labels on the lids, use pen to number labels, print and include a index and your good to go! I also included a word document to print on standard mailing labels âAnything Small Boxâsâ to put on outside of 5X5X1 cardboard box. Takes about 16 minutes per box/lid on standard settings; note, fit will be tight off the printer, open close a few times to wear in. If carful can adjust lock tabs, with heat, on box to affect fit. Alternate, I put lid on box, left in window sill for a couple hours in sun to allow tabs on box to set to perfect fit. I got the boxes from Uline. I got the labels from any office supply store. Enjoy, Reamo Note: I tried to upload the text files for the âindexâ and âbox labelsâ but Thinkiverse wonât let me. That is too bad but you can make your own.
Note: auto generated view of top is show upside down for printing.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/3FFvawvMxos

Heavily inspired by the Goshawk mech of Mecha Front:
http://shimmering-sword.deviantart.com/art/Mecha-Front-Goshawk-383752287 Designed to test how joints with screws will perform, because the printed pins wore out in my previous mech and the joints became loose. approx. 80mm wide and 120mm tall

printed without support
the following parts may need sanding to fit properly:
-the round pins on which the arms pivot
-the triangular pins on the shin guards

and 13 corresponding nuts to assemble it.

description.text:
Had a lot of fun playing with ReconstructMe, it's a great piece of software. This is a scan of my head that was cleaned up with the following software. Blender, MeshLab, Netfab, Meshmixer07.   
The 2 photos in black plastic were smoothed out by evaporating 2 spoons of acetone in a jar on my hot plate at 90 Degrees Celsius for 10 minutes. The method involves setting the heatbed to 110 for 10 minutes then drop the temperature to 90, add the acetone to the bottom of the jar and then lowering the object to be smoothed into the jar on a raised platform making sure no part of the printed object touches any acetone at any time since the evaporation is all that's needed to make the plastic smooth.  
Leave the printed part in for 10 minutes or until done to your liking.  
Note: Acetone is flammable, do not expose to any flame while working with it.

I used slic3r to produce the gcode file and set the support material to 1.5mm and honeycomb and 45 deg. If you decide to print me out please post your photo, I have a bet going with friends who don't believe anyone will print it,... we'll see??

title: Parametric Switch Panel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 9/15/12: v0.69 includes mounting holes, trace output, snap-on Prusa Mendel brackets, and "debug" methods. This is a fully parametric, fully printable switch panel. Currently 26 parameters can be tweaked to change everything from the size of number of switches and panel to the number of throws and throw angle. By adding just a bit of old network cable wire and piece of a brass fastener, the switches can be wired in a number of different configurations, including SPST, SPDT, SPTT. (I'll be adding DPST, DPDT, DPTT configurations next.) Most of these tests I've printed have two switches, but it's very easy to render only one or even more than two. For example, for six switches arranged in two rows of three, just set the switches parameter to [3,2]. VIDEO: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QbMod_f7g1A
VIDEO (in operation): http://youtu.be/qo2-zegLX6g The code is fully commented, and all the parameters are described in the code file. This is a work in progress, but I wanted to get it out there to hopefully start generating feedback. Currently the parameters include number of positions, throw angle (from perpendicular), number and layout of switches, distance apart, extra panel size, hole clearance, panel thickness, paddle thickness/width/length/rounding radius, lever profile, extra lever extension, dedent height, fulcrum diameter, fulcrum support radial and lateral thickness, bare and insulated wire diameters, and several parameters that define how the contact plate is attached. The latest update also includes several parameters for mounting holes and brackets.

If you want a simple set of two SPST or SPDT switches that will pivot on a spare piece of 3mm filament, then just print the STL. Otherwise... Choose some values in the "User-defined values" section, render, and print. Experiment to get a smooth-acting switch -- several factors affect the action, including the thickness of the panel, the fulcrum supports, the dedent height, and others. Insert the levers through the front of the panel using the extra width provided at the center of the holes. Insert a piece of filament or a screw to allow the lever to pivot. The wire channels are experimental. They're intended to provide space to route wires for the switch. The "Plate Contact" seems to work okay, though. To use it, fasten a piece of metal to the end of the lever using super-glue (CA glue) or a screw. (I use a piece cut from a common brass fastener, like the ones shown here: http://amzn.com/B004LWSFAK .) Feed bare wires through the holes in the fulcrum structure, bend the wires around, and twist it back onto itself so that the metal contact bridges the gap when the switch is activated. You can also attach one of the wires to the center tab instead. Take a look at the photos of the black switch panel with the yellow switches. This is wired as a simple on/off switch with some old CAT-5 network cable, and the wires are held in place with globs of hot glue. The three sets of +V/GND go off to the right and are held in place with the mounting bracket. Each set goes off to one device that controlled by one of the switches. The GND (blue) wires from these sets are bunched up and go to the negative or GND terminal of the voltage supply. The white wires travel across the top of the switches and attach to the bottom left of each switch. (This is the "on" position.) Three more white wires go from the bottom right of each switch, around the bottom of the switches, and are bunched together where they connect to the +V terminal of the voltage supply. TIPS:
  • Be sure the metal plates don't get coated with glue if you glue them on. CA glue is not conductive.
  • Use a bit of wire in the glue-up to reinforce it. Drill tiny holes in the metal plates for the wire. Put a drop of glue on the end of the lever, then put the wire in through the glue and turn it a few times to spread the blue inside. Then remove the wire, place the metal plate, and re-insert the wire. Cut off the excess after the glue has dried.

comments.text: When will we see a double throw variation?
comments.author: Roach

comments.text: I'm going to work on it this weekend for the double-position wiring. The current design can be wired up as double throw (or triple throw, or quadruple if you change the number of positions in the SCAD file). Attach the input wire to the back of the switch lever, one output wire to the top position, and the other output wire to the bottom.

description.text: Most of today's smartphones are rectangles with rounded edges. Therefore I have designed a rectangle with rounded edge holder.

The attached STL was generated for my HTC Evo 4G LTE. Open up the openscad file and attach the dimensions, round corner radius, and tolerance to match your phone and printer.
UPDATE: Better scad file and vertical iphone 4s stand
UPDATE2: Scad file now supports a tilt. Angles above 10 degrees not recommended, unless you make your base very wide. Uploaded tilt vertical stand for my EVO 4G LTE as example.
UPDATE3: Refactored and improved scad file. There should be no more strangeness with the bottom of angled stands. Also, steeper angles are supported, I've done up to 25 degrees with the phone on its side. Increase base thickness (variable bo index 1) to avoid having a hole where the phone rests.

description.text:
Still experimenting with slicing/settings etc.  
heres a fairly abstract model of a female nude submerged in water
I needed to close a gap in a IKEA closet.

I encountered a problem with my new Sony Xperia Z1 Compact phone.  I love it and I wanted to buy the official DK32 phone charger stand.  The problem was that as of writing this the DK32 is not available for sale in OZ.  
Anyone with one of these phones will know that they are waterproof.  Concern exists that plugging the standard miniusb requires opening a compartment.  Concern then extends to the constant opening of the compartment resulting in reduced water resistance.  Therefore use of the nearfield charger cables make sense.  
A secondary problem is that it's a bit finicky to ensure the phone charges using the cable automatically (fiddling around to get the charge to happen got too annoying) so I built this holder to work as a stand and an auto  guide for the cable.   
Works well for me.  
"Allow me to present my latest credentials."  Moriarty  
"Oh...they're a bit crutty aren't they?" Bloodnok

title: Flying plastic gliders ... general instructions, videos, and links

description.text:
Resource page for my flying plastic gliders here on thingiverse. Ill maintain a list of links to my best gliders, videos, universal files, etc here. Videos:
http://goo.gl/6o795H
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vPl3sYQPwMY
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUUEdk1EsTg Launcher and tools:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:95765 Link to lots more premium gliders: http://threedsy.com If you want to learn how to design amazing, functional designs for 3d printing, check out my book, Functional design for 3D printing on Amazon! All of My Favorite / Best Gliders and some older ones FREE here on thingiverse Link to help on printing glider wings: http://threedsy.com/blogs/news/7974289-3d-printing-airplane-wings-and-other-membrane-structures

Tips: Printing:
READ THE README FILES!!!!! These are highly engineered objects. They will only work as intended if they are printed using the recommended orientation, layer thickness, and infill settings. You may have to reorient the glider on the print bed if your software does not allow you to change the printing orientation....the first layer must be front-back, the next one left-right....both in line with the fuselage and wings. A 45 degree standard printing orientation will cause the wings to flex asymmetrically, seriously affecting performance (the glider will turn violently at any significant launch speed). The jets may perform ok even if printed a little wrong, due to their more rigid wings. Flying:
Watch the videos. You will need some room. A park or something similar is perfect. Respect bystanders, and wear eye protection....these little guys have a way of coming back to you, and fast. They really do fly. Keep at it, you can get the same results with a properly printed and adjusted glider. Unless you are experienced tossing gliders, it will be much easier to start out with a rubber band and launcher (print one from my launcher and tools thing). Use a long, thin rubber band, not a wide one. Start out small, holding the tail, pulling back a little and releasing until you get the hang of it. Adjust the glider in small increments until it flies straight before going for the big time. Have fun!

description.text:
I made some parts to combine to a Multi-Copter.
With these parts is possible to build a simple Tri V-tail, a Tri with negative V-tail or a Spider Hex.
I will design new parts and upload it. The next part will be the plates for a Quad stile multi-copter. And a drive gear to make a real Tri. This will be a challenge. Update parts:
  • Leg Base
  • Leg Plate
  • T-Couple (60)
    These parts are update for a better fit of the nut. The space between the center and edge of the M3 nuts is gone from 2.5mm to 2.75mm.

Print your favourite parts to complete your design.
Take some carbon or aluminium square tube of 10mm x 10mm. Length is what you want. For the Spider the correct lengths are in Spider.PDF. Then with some M3 x 20 and M3 x 25 bolts, washers and screws you can make your multi-copter frame come to life. Place your beloved KK2 or Multwii flight control board, an other board may need some DIY, on the bottom plate with 5mm standoffs. Screw some motors on. The motor mount are designed for 28mm with 16mm and 19mm screw holes. It is possible to mount the motors upside down, on top or from the bottom. Zip-tie the ECS's on the arms, connect the to your flight controller and motor. Program the flight controller and mount your receiver on the back or front for the Spider. Place some Velcro band through the bottom plate. A slit in the bottom plate is made for this. Place your battery on the bottom of the multi-copter and balance it. Happy Flying.

title: Flower Signs on stems, as pins, as magnets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Recently, I designed a set of road signs http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:298565 and a post and bracket system http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:298560 for display. But even as I was printing road signs, I kept seeing the post as a stem, the bracket as a calyx, and the signs as potential flowers. So, here they are! Everything is modular - separate flower heads (also can be used with pin backs, tie tack backs, or magnets as well as the calyx/bracket - just glue on the back), stems and "greenery" (several styles of leaves, a bud, a spacer). The blazing star comes in two options, complete in one file, or with separate petals and center.

I used PLA in 0.2 mm layers with 2 shells for everything but the stem, which is OK (and faster) with 0.3 mm layers. For the stem, I used 3 shells and only 15% infill for the best compromise of strength and appearance.

comments.text: How do you suggest you put the flower heads on the stem?
comments.author: mashcraft

comments.text: The bracket has a flat front that is glued to the back of the flower head with the open end of the tube part of the bracket facing down. Then, the flower plus bracket can just slide onto the top of the flower stem, with the stem going into the tube. The closed end of the tube stops the stem at just the right height. So, the same stem can accommodate any flower head that has a bracket interchangeably, and any of the leaves (with their tube attachments printed at the same time) can be slipped over the stem first. Hopefully this will work well for you. Thanks for asking!
comments.author: mashcraft

title: Fan extension for "Printrbot Simple, 300mm Y Axis-No Sag!"

description.text: This fan extension is for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242185 The Y extension is very good but as the extruder is very hot, with time it can bend the support. This fan allows to cool the support, avoiding bending or further distorsion. This extensions for the Printrbot simple after 23/10/2013.

• 2 perimeters
  • 70% infill
  • 30 mm/s speed (no more or you can have problem with the arch of the fan).

• 1x 40mm fan (10mm thickness)
  • 1x M3 20 mm
  • 3x M3 16 mm

• First fix the fan on the extension
  • Then fix the extension on the side of the extruder mount.

It'll fit un-sleeved cards, but It wouldn't fit sleeved (the width of the opening not height, have yet to test this). Turns out even though FFG advertises 41x63mm I measured and got 44x66mm. I used some MayDayGames 7075 & they also advertise 41x63mm, but measured 43x65mm & these fit into the model with no alterations. So I guess my point is that I recommend MDG 7075 sleeves if you don't want to alter the 3D model.

description.text:
Magnetic Carriage for StrongPrint http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:329498 Based on Supermagnete 15 mm donut magnet
http://www.supermagnete.fr/eng/R-15-06-06-N The use of magnetic bearings (steel ball over a donut magnet or vice versa) allows 3 key advantages:
  • Strictly no play
  • Rapid assembly disassembly & therefore part exchange
  • Dismantles in case of clash or out of range movement preventing damages to the machine & particularely the print head
    • These could be fitted with contact wires to check if there is a loss of a link & inform the control unit to stop or hold the print job The chosen magnet are just sufficient for the StrongPrint head therefore if you intend to use a heavier print head you should choose to take slightly more powerfull magnets.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302317 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=302317

Using the following options:
length = 139

• Inspired of the orignal egg-bot I designed a interactive variant for egg-decoration.
  • Designed to be easily assembled and printed (no support required if oriented properly while printing)
  • Controlled via serial interface (i use putty to connect, any terminal will do)
  • Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KuiRFXf5oMg

• Direct control (move left/right, rotation forward/reverse) and pen up/down keys like an etch-and-sketch
  • 360 degrees patterns via simple numerical commands. ("Pattern button" followed by one to three digits do select pattern, frequency and width)

• Set-screw with captive nut
  • Inserts tailored for the correct pen dimension (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yXb-T4F5XGk)

• 3d printed parts (PLA)
  • 1 arduino (or standalone atmega328p) with serial connection to host computer
  • 2 driver boards (ULN2003 based)
  • 2 stepper motors (28BYJ48 DC 5V) (~3$ each from China incl. driver board)
  • 1 servo (mini 9g ~3$)
  • a few M4 and M5 screws, washers and nuts
  • a couple of screws to mount the pieces to the base plate
  • 1 spring
  • 1 rubberband
  • "Oogoo" (silicon and corn starch) to the paddings
  • baseplate in any scrap wood material (my was laminated)
  • pencils
  • (optional USB keyboard with stickers)
  • style cheat sheet

• Backlash in the geared steppers was mitigated with software backlash compensation for the rotating axis and with a rubberband for the moving arm. [resolved]
  • Finding the perfect tention so that the egg doesn't slip (making it moving less than expected 360 degrees) [still experimenting]
https://github.com/ahd71/incedm

description.text:
Yet another bearing holder for an LM8UU linear ball bearing.
Prints vertically to avoid the laminar separation common in this type of holder. These should be pretty rugged with 4mm side walls, dual 3mm machine screw mounts and dual 3mm machine screw clamps. Use it stand-alone or incorperate it into your carriage design. 20 September - Added a one-screw version, identical except only one machine screw to secure the LM8UU.

2 perimeters, 3 layers, 0,35mm nozzle, .25mm layer height, 25% fill & 45 degree fill angle.

author: Renstec

title: Honing Guide for Chisels and Blades

description.text:
SO IT SEEMS THAT THE MODEL GOT FLAGGED FOR COPYRIGHT INFRINGEMENT. What. The. ****!!!! It was just INSPIRED by my buddies commercial sharpening guide. I modeled it entirely and made a ton of changes to make it possible to 3D print the thing. Yes, I copied some of the basic ideas of how you set the chisel length for the various angles to be achieved, but EVERY sharpening guide does that.
If somebody wants to flag my designs for copyright infringement simply because I got inspired by something someone else makes, they should contact me directly and we can work it out such that I'm not infringing upon whatever design feature they feel is proprietary to their design. If that isn't something acceptable and my design continues to be flagged then I just won't upload any more designs to Thingiverse...

This honing guide is inspired by one of my buddies commercial honing guides. In addition to the printed parts you will also need:
4 - 1/4x20 flat head machine screws
4 - 1/4x20 nuts (or wingnuts)
4 - 1/4x20 washers
1 - #6 cap screw You will need to print:
1 of each part but for the axle bushings of which you will require 2. Here is what a similar commercial version looks like / costs:
http://www.woodcraft.com/Product/2005515/16822/Veritas-MK-II-Honing-Guide.aspx

Print one of every part except for 2 of the axle bushings. Assembly:
  • Assemble as shown with the Blade Carrier and Blade Carrier bottom
  • Bolt the blade carrier parts together with a 1/4x20 flat head machine screw, washer, and nut
  • Attach the Blade Holder to the Blade Carrier, affix with two more 1/4x20 screws, washers, and nuts.
  • Slide the Registration Jig Depth stop onto the jig
  • Attach the Registration Jig Clamp onto the jig with the last 1/4x20 bolt, washer, and nut
  • Screw the #6 screw into the depth stop. There should be enough "meat" to cut the threads using just the bolt... tho you may want to add extra perimeters as an extra bit of precaution. If you print with PLA, you may want to consider using a tap to cut the threads, or file/use a small drill to cause the least amount of stress as possible while threading it in. Alternatively, you could use a drywall screw and just thread it in JUST enough. It's a small part and easy to print, so play around with it to get the results you like most. If you bust it trying to thread it, just print another. :)
    • Assembly of roller:
  • Sand the axle bushings such that there is a light but not too tight fit between the bushings and the roller. You are looking for a freely revolving fit, with low friction, but not loose. You can add some form of oil based lubricant if you desire as well.
  • Sand the Axle such that there is a tight fit between the bushings and the axle. This should be a firm friction fit which will hold in place when set
  • Superglue the Axle Knob onto the end of the axle, ensuring to not get any excess glue onto the guide, bushings, or carrier parts.
    Insert the roller between the blade carrier bottom sides, and insert the axle.
  • Set the Knob such that the line points UP
    • NOTE: If the axle and bushing fit is too loose, then the eccentric position will not hold, and you will not be able to set the micro-bevel angle via the eccentric. You can still set the angle via repositioning the blade, but it's not as easy/convenient as just twisting the knob. To use:
  • Attach the jig onto the assembled blade carrier, setting the width based on the width of the chisel or blade to be honed.
  • Tighten the nut to affix the jig in place.
  • Insert the blade/chisel between the carrier, and the blade holder
  • Tighten the blade holder to affix the blade in place, aligned with the edge of the jig and inserted to the depth required to set the angle desired.
  • Remove the Jig

author: DasWookie

description.text: As I was opening and closing my extruder more often than I cared to because of filament stripping,  chasing washers and springs all over the place, I got inspired to create a quick and easy alternative to the two tensioning screws.

Remove the original captive nuts in the top of the extruder body.  Attach inner & outer hinges to extruder body.  Take one of the springs from the original tensioning screws and insert it between both hinges.  Attach the top to the outer hinge and close.  The two clips on the top should grab and hold inside the captive nut slots.  If it doesn't, some minor filing may be necessary.

description.text:
Support FIRST Robotics Team 1983 Skunk Works at the 2014 National Championship with a 3D printed bow-tie.  
To wear: Just slip over any normal-sized shirt button and be prepared to be the best dressed at the Championship-watching party.  
"Bow-ties are cool but bow-ties with a skunk are even cooler" ~The 11th Doctor

To Print:
  • Either:
    • Use the .Thing file
    • Place both SkunkWorksBowTieB.stl and SkunkWorksBowTieW.stl together
      All three files should already be pre-sized and oriented in what I have found to be the best print orientation
    • To make your own Dual-Color Bow-tie:
  • Use the Rhino file TwoColorSkunkBowTie.3dm
    This file contains heytiger's origional bow-tie file with several additional blocks. Use Boolean operations to cut-up the model into the sections you wish for each color. The file is set-up so that it has blocks to make the center, bottom, and skunk logo one model and the remainder a second.

Necklace fang.  Can't get much more descriptive than that.  Sized to fit on standard chain necklace, lends a tribal look to projects.  Easily scalable down to 50% and still fits most chains without issue, great for doing tribal inspired jewelry.

Maybe you experienced the same over time: The ball bearings in the primary stage got loose or the wood bend those 0.6mm and finally the bearings are touching the plates on both sides and make noise. This template is intended to laser out and drill the 4mm holes for the upper 2 bearings afterwards, because for that an ordinary low-cost laser isn´t the right tool, aligning the drill head with the cross mark and having the perfect 4mm hole marked only by the laser on top to know when drilled precise.
For that "red" is marking, other colours are cutting. Best take a material less prone to flex like precision-5mm-acryl-gs. Optionally instead of 2 nuts on the back you can replace 1 of them with the disk going behind the main plate. This should make it less prone to flex. Works as drop-in improvement.

I have a very nice set of about 30 different brightly colored gel pens that I would like to use with Silhouette.The inner diameter of the adapter closely matches the diameter of those pens. You will have to adjust that based on what you have. You will also need M5 bolt with M5 nut nut to act as a set screw, or adjust the nut well size to match different screw/nut. The dimensions in the files may be wrong -- I had to fudge them so my printer produces desired output.
(Edit: combined knob and adapter in one file, exposed customiztion parameters for OpenJsCad)

1) Print the pen adapter.
2) Slide M5 nut into the nut well.
3) Make sure that it accepts M5 screw in its final position.
4) Print the knob part.
5) Use a vice to press fit the knob over the head of round-headed M5 screw.
6) Insert the pen so that ball point sticks out about 0.5 mm. Fix it in that position with a screw.
7) Insert the adapter into Cameo and lock it. To customize:
1) go to http://joostn.github.io/OpenJsCad/
2) paste the contents of silhouette-pen-adapter.jscad into "Playground" text area
3) Click "Update" button
-- OpenJsCad should render the adapter and create a form with a list of adjustment parameters.
4) adjust the parameters and hit "Update" button
5) generate save STL
6) optionally select "knob" from a drop down menu
7) generate and save STL for knob.

This is just a more complex polygon version of the Turner's Cube.  A friend made me a cube with his CNC machine years ago, and since then I've always wanted to make one like this.  
There are some pretty tough overhangs on here.  Perhaps it would be a little better with a solid base.
I had to print with support and honestly, it came out a little rough.  The overhangs on the tops of the lower circles are particularly rough.  I probably spent a good hour with the old hobby knife...

title: Stanford Easter Bunny - Voronoi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi all, I needed a cool mesh to test some true voronoi patterns. And in the spirit of Easter;
the Stanford Bunny seemed like the perfect subject! The cell-center distribution for the voronoi patterns was generated using charge particle simulations:
The particles can move freely within a 1mm thick voxel model of the bunny. They repel and attract each other. And over time they form a near perfect distribution across the surface. Next, the 1mm wide voronoi pattern was generated within the same 1 mm thick voxel model, resulting in round 1mm wires. And finally the voxel model was polygonized using a marching cubes algorithm, and cleaned using VCG lib functions. Stanford_Bunny - Voronoi pattern stl
Is based on single charges, producing a smooth distribution and a honeycomb like pattern. Stanford_Bunny - Voronoi2 pattern stl
Is based on sets of 2 linked charges, or lines actually. This produces slightly elongated cells. Resulting in a more more crackly pattern. And although it is not a derivative,
hat-tip to Roman Hegglin's "Stanford Bunny Voronoi style":
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:291323 Happy Easter everyone! Info on the Bunny here:
http://www.gvu.gatech.edu/people/faculty/greg.turk/bunny/bunny.html
http://graphics.stanford.edu/data/3Dscanrep/ Original copyright info:
"Please be sure to acknowledge the source of the data and models you take from this repository. In each of the listings below, we have cited the source of the range data and reconstructed models. You are welcome to use the data and models for research purposes. You are also welcome to mirror or redistribute them for free. Finally, you may publish images made using these models, or the images on this web site, in a scholarly article or book - as long as credit is given to the Stanford Computer Graphics Laboratory. However, such models or images are not to be used for commercial purposes, nor should they appear in a product for sale (with the exception of scholarly journals or books), without our permission."

Scale as needed.
Current size is 10cm
Wires are ca 1mm.

comments.text: I love this bunny. I printed it at ~.3mm layer height as a quick easter decoration. I filled it with a small bit of easter grass while printing. When it was 50% done, I filled it up to the 25% mark with paper easter grass. I wrapped a small amount of candy (10 m&ms) in saran wrap for food safety, and used them to hold down the easter grass. The paper grass doesn't melt and keeps the candy off of the heated printer bed. I then printed the rest of the bunny around the candy and grass. This print only uses 10g of material, so it's not much of a waste if you have to break it open to get the candy. PLA is biodegradable anyway!

title: Spacer for Creator X Raffle Alu Cooling blocks

description.text:
I wanted to use Carl's Alu block with the stock Flashforge Creator X extruder set up so I made a set of spacers to get the filament to line up with the thermal barrier. This is the part I'm referring to:
http://shop.raffle.ch/shop/alu-dual-cooling-block/ The other option is to print or purchase a feeder for the makerbots but for now this is my solution. I am still deciding on what to do about the feeder. I might just spring for the 3in1 machined feeder since it is very popular.

Simple to print. Just use 100% infill and 1 shell. I used .2 layer height for my spacers but these pieces are pretty thin so it might be better to print the 1mm and sand it down. I ended up using 1 x 1mm and 1x .5mm spacer combo for my set up. You will need a longer screw to accommodate the spacer. I am using this one: http://www.mcmaster.com/#91294a126/=rlve60
The other option is to countersink the screw holes in the mount to get a longer reach but new screws are cheap and you won't have to modify anything.

I made a simple little antenna stand for my SDR dongle.

SCV8UU linear bearing block is the ideal replacement for printed or laser cut MendelMax Y-Carriage. Simplified design by dumping the 2 stage print platform. The single piece of print platform is now seated directly on top of the SCV8UU's flat surface. It will slide above the aluminium extrusion with 1mm clearance. The Y-Axis belt is clamped onto one of the SCV8UU to transfer linear movement to the print platform. Complete MendelMax 1.5 kit with SCV8UU Y-Carriage available from Blomker Industries http://stores.ebay.com/Blomker-Industries VIDEO : http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0oZWGwWIWXo&feature=youtu.be

Using SCV8UU with Jmil's Compact Y Rod Holders (Thing:24510) is perfect because the print platform will be positioned slightly above the front aluminium extrusion with 1mm clearance. This allow the print platform to slide above the extrusion and not limiting the Y-Axis travel distance. Print a copy of the SCV8UU T5 Belt Clamp and assemble with the following material : 4 x SCV8UU
2 x M3(35mm) bolt
2 x M3 nut
1 x Printed T5 Belt Clamp for SCV8UU
1 x Print Platform (Can be 3mm Aluminium Plate or 9mm MDF)

title: Gopro vibration isolation mount for multirotor

description.text: Inspired by David Windestals design from flite test. I use silicone tubing to hang the mount from my quad copter. See photos. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/e9vjlpW3ofq

Printed with PLA,10% fill and .3mm layer height Other parts 8 - 4 X 20mm bolts 8 - 4mm nuts Silcone tubing cut to length that you desire

  • Cut silicone tubing to length you require

  • Insert 4mm nuts into silcone tubing with bolt - insert far enough that the tubing covers all of the nut but the hole

  • Insert 4mm bolts through holes in the base and scew into the nuts in the tubing, the tubing will get pinched between the nut and the mout securing it.

  • Use the 4 counter sunk washers to attach the tubing to your frame again the tubing will get pinched between the nuts and the washers.
    • The mount will hang from the multirotor isolating it from vibration and elimiating the jello effect.

On many occasions I have printed parts that have a large surface area. Getting these parts off the print table can be a bear.  Even once you can get something to get under the edge of the part it takes a lot of hand force to get the part to let go. What usually happens is the printer slides around on the table surface taking away a lot of the mechanical advantage; almost scooted the printer off the table a couple times.  The printer has rubber feet on the corners but they don't grip the table top. So, I created these little corners that are screwed down to the table. These corners capture the printer feet/corners to eliminate this problem.  
I used #8 X 3/4 inch wood screws to mount the printer corners. You will need 12 screws. But most any size flat head screw could be used. Along with the STL file, I have included the native file (SolidWorks) and an IGS version so you can modify the part if you want. IE: make sides taller or change screw hole size.  It takes about 20 minutes to print on "low" print settings. Print four, one for each corner.  Enjoy, Reamo  
Printing this part is a good example of "hard to get off the table". I added a chamfer on one edge of the part to make it somewhat easier to remove from the print table.

title: Reci CO2 Laser Head Direct Mount

description.text:
This thing is for mounting a focus lens directly to a Reci W6 laser tube. I think it should work as is on any Reci tube, but it parameterized, so it can easily be adapted for other tubes. Why would you want to mount the lens directly to the tube? I suppose for most setups it would only be used for testing the laser. For my purposes, I plan on moving the whole laser tube on my large CNC machine, so I should be able to put this to good use (I am not going to steer the beam, I am going to steer the whole tube). Works great. Very snug fit on both the laser and the laser head. Video of it in action here (it is the green part):
http://youtu.be/on1uARh9xOU The laser head I am using is this one: http://lightobject.com/1820mm-Laser-head-w-air-assisted-Ideal-for-K40-machine-P701.aspx Special thanks to TrevM for making the really useful thread library!
Printed at 101% (for PLA shrinkage), use slic3r (0.1 layers, 100% fill) and fits the laser tube and laser head perfectly.

comments.text: Just to be clear, it is not moving the whole tube that is the issue. It is the narrow glass tube inside the laser tube that will break first.  The narrow tube is the one that carries the water (so it's heavy and has a bit of inertia) and is very poorly supported.  The end near the output is supported by a single piece of glass tubing (the water outlet), the spring on the end provides no structural support.

title: PrintrPlate - Printrbot Full Build Tray (On Steroids)

description.text:
This full plate contains all the 3D parts you need to build a new printrbot in one run. This is Self Replication in its purest form ! It contains all the most recent versions of the base parts, some were replaced by enhanced versions. Please note that this plate contains all parts to build the printrbot base. The extruder and all its accessories is on a seperate plate here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30787
 update 2012/12/18 : fixed a little manifold error , thanks to Pierre-Olivier Ceffis
removed the 10t pulleys from the plate. An aluminium pulley gives better print results.
 update 2013/02/06 : ( V3 ) re-arranged the pieces so that pieces that tend to detach from the heatbed are pointing towards the center of the plate. It's hot & cosy there... The newest version also stays away from the corners of your build platform , to avoid bumping into clipses at the corners of your glass plate if you have one...

Download the most recent version of the plate STL ( currently version v3 ) Please make sure that your printer is well calibrated before starting to print this plate. It uses almost the whole surface of your heatbed. Also make sure that your heatbed is level for the same reason as above. I rounded off the corners of the plate to stay away from the borders of the heatbed, where typically some screws are in your way. A few tips :
  • I use 4 rounds of skirt when slicing the model, that way you have plenty of time to verify if your printbed is level & the height of your extruder is constant along the whole surface of it.
  • Make sure that the clamps holding the glass to the heatbed are on the outside of the white line marking the outside of your heatbed PCB. You don't want your extruder to bump into one...
  • Duration of the print is 8h+ make sure that the room temperature remains +/- constant , or your parts may start to warp ( don't leave it printing overnight in a cold garage )...
    • Have patience, and good luck !

Fits a TP-Link TL-MR3020 with a USB key cut-out. Version 1 designed for a 3mm diameter material and assumes a 0.001 inch line weight for vector cutting. ** Hole locations were off in v1 -- found that USB cable ends were often too broad to fit securely. Please use v2 instead. Version 2 designed according to Ponoko requirements (0.01mm line weight and blue colour. Has an expanded single hole for power & network cables rather than two. Ideal for LibraryBox/PirateBox applications requiring access to an external power source. You may need to do some gluing, as the design doesn't quite stay snapped together when laser cut. Please feel free to fork & modify this design! :)

Designed in Inkscape with a base template generated by Makercase.
You may need to do some gluing as the template doesn't quite hold when snapped.

title: Tennis Racket Vibration Dampener (using a pencil-end eraser)

description.text: Hasn't seen any useful thing really about tennis on Thingiverse yet. So I decided to create one. This is a dampener for tennis rackets/racquets. It nearly didn't cost me anything.

"FIX" includes one piece with a position fixer and a flat piece (You'll see what I mean) with my initial. "NORMAL" includes two flat pieces (one with my initial on). "DE-INITIALED" includes one flat piece without my initial. (Knew you guys wouldn't like my initial on it... )
See material list and instructions on the instruction page

BOM:

  • You'll need:

  • M3 or1/8" nut and screw of 10mm or 3/8" (the best choice) or longer(1)

  • The printed parts. you'll need two flat pieces (NORMAL) or one flat and one fixer (FIX)

  • Super glue or any other kind of glue that could hold rubber and plastic together (optional but highly highly recommended)

  • A rubber from a random old wooden pencil or any rubber cylinder that has diameter that's around 7mm (between 5/16" and 1/4") (use a piece longer than 5mm at least)
    (I used the rubber form a papermate mechanic pencil. )

  • A utility knife (I used a swiss army knife. scissors might work), and an allen wrench for your screw

Instructions:
    1. prepare your stuff.

  • cut the rubber into 4 pieces that are about 1mm thick or thicker. the thicker the more dampening the dampener will be (I guess...but not too thick of course)

  • glue the rubber pieces to the round hollow areas of each piece of the printed parts. (you could pass this step. but then it would be really maddening later)

  • screw it on the racket. hope you do know where on the racket. (if not see my picture.)

I threw this together to cheer up a grandmother when she was in the hospital for a few days. Perhaps it can cheer up a few more grandparents here. It is comprised of two parts, a placard and a removable stand. I have provided a second version of the placard, modified for a grandfather instead of a grandmother.
I printed this on a 3D Systems ProJet 650, a full-color plaster printer. It should also work well on an FDM machine, although you will unfortunately miss out on the colors.
Most users will probably want to use the "unnamed" STL file, since this doesn't say "Love, Steve". Users with Solidworks, however, can download the SolidWorks files and change the text as they like (i.e. sub in their own name for "Steve"). I have also included "unified assembly" STL's in which the stand is already seated inside the placard.

comments.text: I hope your grandma gets better soon, too. Good luck!

description.text:
The Master line has been designed and constructed so as to keep in order the lines of your kite. Compatible with all makes and models of kites to 4 (or 5 lines), the system has 4 (or 5) connectors, each consisting of two identical halves which mate to "embrace" every single line without squeezing it. During normal operation of each kite, the line will host a connector. At the end of the session, when separate lines by 'kite is sufficient to interconnect the elements of the Master line in the same order in which you disconnect from the kite. The system ensures that the lines do not cross and can always maintain the correct order to be reconnected to the kite without the need to unroll the entire length, avoiding any possibility of knotting or tangling the four lines.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XCw6HihptwI

description.text:
I produced these for a family member suffering from Crohn's Disease (affecting her intestines). She got a real laugh out of them. Which is good, because drawing intestines in SolidWorks turned out to be darned difficult.
I have a hard time imagining anyone else would want to hang a pair of intestines from their earlobes, but just in case, I figured I'd upload it here.
The part is inscribed with some text in one of the photos, but I removed the inscription from the part files that I uploaded. The part came out great on a ProJet 4500 full-color plastic printer. The part will also come out on any ProJet full-color plaster printer (a.k.a. a "ZPrinter" or a 3D Systems "x60"), but it will be quite fragile.

The part in the photo was printed on a ProJet 4500 full-color plastic printer. If you want to print in color at a lower price, the part will also come out on any ProJet full-color plaster printer, but will be quite fragile.
If color isn't important, this part came out quite well for me on a Projet 3500, and I would expect it to work well on an SLA machine as well.
For color printing, grab the WRL file (aka VRML).

Apparently no one on the internet wanted to actually provide this file in a usable format for someone who might have a laser/router (even printing it onto large format paper would be helpful), so I figured that - again - I should save the internet with my file conversion-fu. This was taken from the Rostock Github plywood.scad file, converted to STL, then manually converted to a real part/drawing in solidworks (OpenSCAD didn't do anything when I tried to export as DXF).
Remember designers - even if you made something by hand, providing CAD files helps builders understand what they are making. :)
Make it! See Rostock description for info on thickness. I think he said 9mm plywood is suggested.

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

Prints in 2 parts, the dock has a hole where you can fit an original magnet charger connector that you bought somewhere (On amazon for around 9 Euros).  
Or you can print the connector part and solder a 0.75mm copper wire to a stripped USB cable (look at the last photo). It prints as a seperate part because the wire-holes tend to close up due to the plastic shrinking or sagging, so you'll have to drill the holes to get the wire through.

description.header: Using a magnet charger connector bought somewhere:

description.text:
• Magnet charger connector
  • Knife

• Print the dock part
  • Cut the hole at the back to an U-shape so you can lay the charger cable through
  • Hot-Glue the connector in place and put the cable in the U-shaped channel to lead it to the back and then out through the cut hole.

• Salvaged USB Cable (or just 2 pole cable and USB connector)
  • 0.75mm to 1mm copper wire (about 50 to 70mm)
  • Isolating tape or shrink tubing to isolate the wires against each other
  • Optionally: Some kind of magnet that fits the 10x1.5mm slot
  • Sanding paper
  • Soldering iron
  • Wire stripper/cutter

• Print both parts (or use the build plate STL)
  • Drill/Clean the holes:
    • The big holes from the bottom are 2.5mm
    • The angled holes on the top are 0.75-1mm (you have to get the copper wire through without much wiggling space)
  • Get some 0.75-1mm copper wire and solder it to a salvaged USB-Cable (Red is +, Black is -, isolate the other colored wires, those are for data)
  • Put the wires through the holes that they stand out about half a milimeter (+ is on the top of the phone, - on the bottom, do NOT reverse the poles, your phone may be damaged!) and sand them even to make the best possible contact.
  • Optionally get some small magnets to put in the slot, it helps centering the phone automatically. (I used two 5 x 1.5mm neodymium disc magnets and glued them in)

The Open Crowd Project is a collaborative project using 3D scanning and printing technology to create a â€œcrowdâ€ of people printed with 3D printers. The goal of this project is to collaborate with people who may be in different geographic areas, but who are willing to come together and collaborate through an online space. We encourage everyone that is interested in this project to participate! All you have to do is follow the instructions provided on the â€œparticipateâ€ page of The Open Crowd Project website and weâ€™ll create a 3D model of you, 3D print it, and include you in the crowd! By participating in The Open Crowd Project, you will have the opportunity to see a representation of yourself in a group of people that have never before been assembled in physical space. Through this project, we hope to offer the opportunity to see yourself standing alongside others, therefore reinforcing a sense of togetherness between people who may otherwise be strangers. More information at http://www.theopencrowdproject.com

Instructions on how to participate are located here: http://www.theopencrowdproject.com/participate/ This is a collaborative project, so we encourage everyone to get involved! If you're interested in finding out more information about it, please check out The Open Crowd Project website at http://www.theopencrowdproject.com

remixed_from.author: mooslug
remixed_from.title: Phial of Salts prop - Bioshock Infinite

title: Phial of Salts Bottle - Full-Color Solid

description.text:
This is a full-color, 3D printable model of the Phial of Salts bottle from Bioshock Infinite. It is intended for printing on a 3D Systems full-color plaster or plastic printer, although it should work on any monochrome printer as well.
It is an adaptation of Mooslug's Phial of Salts bottle, which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:97870. I took the 3 parts and placed them into a single assembly. I also modified the bottle so that it's one solid piece, rather than hollow. This makes it possible to print in weaker materials such as plaster.
I then added Mooslug's artwork (the "Invigorating Salts" logo and the stopper flame) directly to the 3D model and saved it as a VRML. This full-color model can be printed on any full-color printer from 3D Systems or ZCorp (or through Shapeways). I have also attached a monochrome STL file, which can be printed on any printer, but will unfortunately not come out in color.
Enjoy! And special thanks to Mooslug, who did the real heavy lifting with his original version.
If you want to get this model in full color, I believe you can submit the wrl (aka VRML) model file w/ textures to Shapeways for production in sandstone, or a 3D Hubs member on a ZPrinter or 3D Systems x60.
If you want to get this model in full color, you should be able to submit the wrl (aka VRML) model file to Shapeways for production in sandstone, or a 3D Hubs member on a ZPrinter or 3D Systems x60.

description.text: This is a model of the robot Team 753 The High Desert Droids entered into the 2010 FIRST competition. Created in Autodesk Inventor 2010. I have only uploaded the assembly and not the components because it would be a very large file and would take a very long time to re-associate all of the component files.

comments.text: Unfortunately, Inventor's files are linked rather than instanced into an assembly so the .IAM assembly file will not work without all the associated components included in the upload. You can do this simply with a "Pack n Go" from Vault (assuming you are using Vault for file management) that will put all the required files into a target folder.  Then just zip the whole mess up and try to send it along again.  Inventor users can then open it.  On bogusness of Inventor is that it is NEVER backward compatible, so let everyone know what version of inventor it was exported from.

remixed_from.title: MK8 Extruder Upgrade (Flashforge Creator Dual Extruder)

title: Extruder Upgrade for Flashforge, and CTC

description.text:
This Thing is featured on the 3D Printing Today Podcast.
http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com This is a derivative of the Thing uploaded by Coldstone. This thing is meant as an upgrade to the OEM, unsprung feeder parts used in older Flashforge Creators and in the CTC machines This is the spring armed feeder upgrade design first upload by whosawhatsis and redesigned over and over... In this design the lever arms can hold the fluted bearings used by these Rep1 clone makers. In this derivative I have separated the backplates that attach to the stepper motors so that the distance of the hot ends is not fixed and so the user can remove one motor for cleaning and servicing. i included the 2 peg files from Coldstones original upload.

I used XT due to it's higher temp capabilities, but ABS should be OK. PLA... no. The heat from the motors will soften PLA and the lever arms will distort. I tried to add support via Simplify3D... but it seems one can't export the supports into an stl that way. The levers can be printed without support, but they hold the shape better with.
You will need some flat head M3 screws; 2x18mm, 2x9mm and 2x6mm. I use lighter springs due to the aggressive bladded, spur gears used on the stepper motors. These can be purchased at harbor freight or at a larger HW store such as Home Depot.

comments.text: What size spring is required?
comments.author: danielolver1

comments.text: I cannot recall. I suggest you print it and measure. For sure you want it to be strong enough, but too heavy a spring could deform the filament. I had to replace the springs a few times before i got it just right.
comments.author: danielolver1

comments.text: Nice  Job
comments.author: Coldstone

comments.text: Thanks... the supports on the levers did not export. Sorry.

title: Mass Effect Carnifex (first draft) (Updated version in description)

description.text: EDIT: The newer, more detailed and revised to print on smaller beds version is located here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:455678 This is my version of the Carnifex Hand Cannon from the Mass Effect Games. This is not the finished version, but it's as far as I got on my own. I'm waiting to upload the finished version until I can get a copy of it printed for myself. I had to hire someone to fix a section I had trouble with, and I want to be the first to test out the finished design. (the curved section is the only thing that got reworked, the rest is the same as this version.) It should be a 1:1 ratio for a full-sized print (assuming Solidworks exports the .stl file and keeps it in inches). The holes between parts should be the size of 1.75mm filament. The idea was that it would help align and hold it together while the glue is curing. Not sure how this will work until it is printed. I'm going to make a seperate entry here for the finished version, since I can't claim all the credit for the work on that one. This version I did on my own, and I thought I did rather well for my first Solidworks project.

description.text:
The Design Team over here at MakerBot have perfected the art of making links for this MakerBot Watch that print in place without needing to be assembled. Once removed from the build plate, they move freely, and can be taken apart and snapped back together. Feel free to download the design and adapt it for your own purpose.  
Mix and match your favorite colors to create an awesome watch for any occasion! Contrast the band with the pop-out bezel, or make links in multiple colors for an interesting two-tone band.  
Created by Matt Kroner, John Briscella, and John Dimatos

For best results, print with the following settings:  
Face:  
Infill = 0  
Layer Height = .25  
Shells = 0  
Everything Else:  
Infill = 10  
Layer Height = .25  
Shells = 1

A thing to debug my printerbot's bridging problems.
A variety of shapes on two different layers - otherwise it tries bridging the whole thing in one go. Printing this has been somewhat enlightening. There seems to be a problem bridging to a single layer wall. Bridgetest2.stl has several wall thickness and heights.
The bridges are all at the same height and Slic3r spans the lot in one pass. If you have a gcode viewer such as the one in repetier it can be interesting to see what the slicer does.

title: Mesostructured Cellular Materials Generator: Customizable version of AndreasBastian's prototypes

description.text:
Hats off to AndreasBastian's outstanding design with thing:289650!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:289650 This customizable version uses similar geometry in a parametric scad file, allowing control over some key variables, notably the following:
width and height of sheet
base pattern size
type of node structure (triangular or square)
number of turns in the pattern
sheet thickness
line width Also included is a zip file with a stripped down version of the scad that can be easily included and called within other designs. My hope is that this helps others use AndreasBastian's great work within designs where these unique material properties are useful. Already working on a few....

This is a gothic cathedral window with a simple stained glass pattern.  The glass pieces are made from different colours of translucent PLA.  The individual pieces snap fit into the stone window frame.

This thing was made on a MakerBot Replicator 2 using PLA.
No scaling is required.
All pieces are printed in standard resolution.
Try to print the long glass pieces vertically on the build platform and use rafts. This will give you the best transparency.
The smaller glass were printed flat on the build platform, but you can try those vertically too.
Use 100% infill for the smaller glass pieces.
Use whatever variety of translucent colours you have.
Once you have printed them, they fit snuggly into the respective holes in the stone frame.
You may have to sand some the edges a bit to make them fit.
The smaller pieces are the hardest to handle.

title: Earbud Reel by Terminus Scaled to mm

description.text: Just a quick remix to scale this to mm to avoid any conversion inconveniences.

comments.text:
Terminus, thanks again for the Blender suggestion.
I actually just used Blender to fix a file a friend sent me, and it turned out great despite the original file's failings.
comments.author: ccbdav

comments.text:
I bought an Afinia because it had the best reviews at the time, but had no idea it would do most of the work for me. Didn't learn that 'till I hung around here..
I'll look into the software you mentioned, particularly the free version of Netfabb. I've seen the names before and they must be in wide use.
You might try designing with Blender... freeware with a huge support community. Wiki.. youtube vids.. etc. To output printable STLs you'll need to grasp only a tiny portion of its capabilities... maybe 3%. It was originally intended as a tool to create 3D animation, film making.. to do complex rendering and similar.
But it became popular with the printer people. The latest versions either include a dedicated 3D-Printing specific "tool box" or that can be d/loaded and installed as an addon. It checks for design errors which will likely cause printing problems.... calculates part volume... a few other handy things..
Metric is fine i guess... But at this small printing scale I'm mostly using decimals anyway.. not fractions, not feet or yards.. And on the bigger scale highway signs are still in miles so I rarely get lost..
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
The Afinia software sounds pretty rad...it's amazing that it intuitively knows (or guesses) the units even with "none" units.
As a Printrbot Simple user and an extreme design neophyte who has yet to design a model from scratch (a situation I hope will be remedied as soon as this semester is over!), I personally use Repetier-Host/Slic3r and Cura (Cura is, I think, by Ultimaker but has stock options for many other brands of printers) for my slicing needs. Both are quite capable, but sometimes have problems with files that may have been created in non-discreet units such as these earbuds. I greatly prefer Cura's slicing, but that's irrelevant just now.
While it is simple enough to scale an item in either environment for a quick print by a factor of 25 or 25.4, I frequently have to cut plated builds due to the small size of the Simple---even with the upgraded 185/100/165 XL build size. For cutting and parting out I utilize Netfabb, which was used for this thing. Probably not the best option, but it does work fairly well and is free. I do this when I come across a great thing---such as this one---that others may not know how to modify or cut. I actually "downgraded" from an ~8"x8"x8" (200x200x200 mm) build area of the Printrbot Plus v2.1 to the 4"x4"x4" (100x100x100 mm) build area of the 2014 Maker's Simple (kit) due to some serious issues with the former. The 2014 Maker's Simple has been a treat, and the only real issues I've had with it were software related. I again digress...
I am also still sort of stuck in the SAE loop, but have been trying to become more metric-centric since becoming heavily involved in robotics and 3D printing. I am the suck at math, but I have been trying to convert every measurement I come across to metric recently. It's a process, but anything that seems annoying or inconvenient can be made fun with a little creativity.
For what it's worth, it's strange that the same people who tell you they recently ran a "5k" furl a brow when they ask you for directions and you reply with something like, "turn left in 3.2 kilometers"...go figure. Hipsters are only hip when they can simply follow the crowd.
comments.author: ccbdav

comments.text: Terminus, I am sorry, but I don't use or have any knowledge about Afinia software.  Please let me know if you figure it out and I will remove this remix of your fantastic thing.
comments.author: ccbdav

comments.text:
oh no.. don't get me wrong. I'm flattered you posted it. Thanks.
(BTW, I recently found this in someone's collection: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:210142http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... It's very similar in shape but has a hinge ...? Predates mine by a month. Credit to walter... gmta :)
Anyway, if people are having difficulty converting from SAE to metric I'd like to fix that at the design stage. However, since most of my tools, machines, measuring instruments and my brain work with SAE, it would be nice if there were a software solution.
Blender offers 3 choices for measuring units: Metric, Imperial and None. I work in the nondescript 'None". It can be light years, yards or nanometers. Blender doesn't know or care.
But for some reason, Afinia's import routine understands that an STL which Blender exports as 64 units wide is not 64 inches wide. It also knows something 2.7 "none"-units wide is not 2.7 cm wide.
Although it is proprietary and offers comparatively few adjustments and tweaks, Afinia has great software imo. It's commercial quality... conserves time and material at every point. Slicing never takes more than a couple minutes.. and it essentially automates the whole printing process for non-geek types.
So, I'm wondering what print software others are using which apparently has trouble correctly sizing Blender's output STLs. That info might be helpful. I might d/load it if possible and play around with it.
comments.author: ccbdav

comments.text:
I d/loaded your .stl file, opened it in Afinia print software and it reports this thing is "69.04mm" wide.
Then I opened it in Blender, and it is also seen as 69.04 units wide. There it was scaled way down to roughly 2.7 units wide, and exported as a new STL.
The scaled down version was opened in Afinia, and it again shows 69mm wide... the proper size for printing.
Do you have any idea how or why Afinia software sees no difference between the two? Might Blender's stl exports, like Netfab's, include info about the units of length used, so that one's print software opens it properly?
I've had only one complaint about conversion issues but evidently it is not an isolated incident. I'd like to learn enough about the situation to design a "fix" which will apply to everyone.
comments.author: Terminus

title: Fan mount for the UP MIni extruder stepper

description.text:
Only works with this mod http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:300335/#files
And this mod
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:304213 Fan mount for the modified UP Mini extruder stepper. Attached with two magnets that are epoxied into the fan mount. two steel washers are epoxied to the stepper mount and wind barrier.

Only works with this mod http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:300335/#files
And this mod
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:304213 Watch for interference of the fan and printer housing when the extruder is far right. Attached with two 1/2" dia x 1/8" thick neodymium magnets that are epoxied flush into the fan mount. two 1/2" x .090 steel washers are epoxied to the stepper mount and wind barrier. Look at the drawing for more information. The 12 volt 15 or 20 mm fan is wired directly into the existing fan wires. The fan pushes air away from the stepper. The fan bolt hole dimensions are 32mm between bolt centers. You will need to tap four 3mm x .5 holes in the fan mount and buy some 3mm-.5 x 10mm screws to mount the fan to the fan mount. You may need to lengthen your heater wires.

author: jeeplvr

description.text:
Here are a set of Platonic dice.  Five stl files and the five openSCAD programs that created them are provided.  Each openSCAD program contains a module that makes a rounded Platonic solid.  Variables are an overall scale factor and a radius for rounding.  One of polymakers fonts, thing:13677, ArchitectsDaughter, was used to label the surfaces.
Dice are a popular topic on Thingiverse.  A search using "dice" yielded nearly a hundred hits. Most of the dice have sharp edges but thing:29055 by KillerGardevoir is a nicely rounded set which rolls well.  As the rounding radius of the Platonic dice is increased a point is reached where they resemble KillerGardevoir's dice.  Further increases turn the Platonic dice into near spheres.
I printed the dice directly on the build platform with a modest amount of infill.  They are small objects which print quickly.

title: T4 Quadcopter Mini 250 Drone (5 inch props)

description.text:
This is a mini version of my T4 Quadcopter design. It uses the same concepts but is completely redesigned to fit into the "250" class of mini quadcopters.
This design is suitable for 5" props. If you are after something a little bigger there is now also the T4 Quadcopter Mini 315 that supports up to 8" props and a 2200mah battery - or just use the longer arms on this model if you don't need the battery space.
Check out the whole "T" copter family:
  • TX8 Octocopter
  • T6 Hexacopter
  • T4 Quadcopter (10" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 315 (7-8" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 250 (5" props)
  • Tubular Crossfire 2 quadcopter
    I've added a post on the forums over at DIY Drones for discussing and improving these designs.

    Videos

  • FPV flight by Abormor
  • Build video playlist
  • Build video 1: Body assembly
  • Build video 2: Install motors
  • Build video 3: ESCs and power
  • Build video 4: Flight control
  • Frame strength testing

• completely 3D printable (without support)
  • fully assembled frame weight less than 110 grams!
  • strong, simple assembly with no bolts to save weight! Everything is secured using 2.5mm zip ties.
  • includes three arm options - 24mm, 28mm, and 30mm motor cup (inside diameter). The 30mm cup has slots for 3mm motor bolts (the others are 2mm).
  • strong braced tube section arms with plenty of room to conceal motor wiring
  • designed for a 3S battery (1000 - 1500mah) located right in the centre of rotation/thrust (88 x 38 x 22mm capacity).
  • plenty of space to mount ESCs - concealed but still well ventilated for cooling.
  • top plate has space for a variety of flight controllers and a Mobius style camera. It also features 3mm mounting holes so stand-offs could be used to add an additional deck of components. Alternatively two hex holes are available to add 3D printed posts and rear upper deck.
  • RF "invisible" frame - as opposed to carbon fiber or aluminium
  • Sketchup file included so you can make changes to suit yourself

    History

    2 September 2014
    Legs for your T4 Mini are now available.
    12 August 2014
    Version 1.4
    New vibration isolating top plate option. This option is compatible with previous body and all other components. It replaces the top plate with one that has mounting points for 65 gram vibration damping balls that then connect to a new floating plate to hold your flight controller and camera.
    New files:

  • T4MiniVibrationTopPlate.stl
  • T4MiniVibrationFloatingPlate.stl
    Also updated Body.stl to slightly raise the arms giving a bit more strength in the arm sockets.
    20 July 2014
  • Added T4MiniArm30mm7inch.stl so that "blackdice" can experiment with bigger (7") props. Also added T4MiniArm28mm7inch.stl
    12 July 2014
    Version 1.3
  • Added T4MiniTrayShallow.stl as requested by "p25o1". This low profile bottom tray reduces the available height to 7mm (compared to 14mm original).
    (no other files have changed)
    1 June 2014
    Version 1.2
  • added T4MiniArm30mm.stl which has a 30mm internal cup to fit motors such as the Lumenier 2206-11. This arm also has slots for 3mm motor bolts (the others are 2mm).
  • T4MiniBatteryPin.stl has also been updated to add a small tab to make it easier to install and remove the battery pin.
    (no other files have changed)
    31 May 2014
    No changes to the files but I've just replaced my Multistar ESCs with 12amp Afro ESCs (SimonK firmware) and its made a huge improvement. Even the cheapo Multistar 1704 motors sound better. I'm about to fit some Lumenier 2206-11 motors so we'll see how that goes...
    26 April 2014
    Version 1.1
  • improved method for attaching top plate and bottom tray to the body.
  • slightly increased zip tie hole sizes to make them easier to thread through.
  • thicker top plate (2mm) with rearranged rubber band and hex post mounting points at the rear.
  • new posts and plate added to give an additional layer for mounting the receiver or other items.
  • new slots in the rear of the bottom tray so cables can be threaded up the back of the T4 to suit some flight controllers.

I printed all parts in PLA, 0.25mm layers with 40% infill, 2 shells and 3 top/bottom layers. Feel free to experiment. I didn't play around too much with the settings as these gave me a good strong result.
Fitting the top plate and bottom tray
Both the top plate and bottom tray are designed to slide from front to back (at 45 degrees) as they are being fitted into the body. In particular the top plate needs to be pressed firmly down onto the 8 angled guides as you slide it back. Once in place the top plate will clip onto the smaller bumps near the rear cable tie mount (just above the rear arms). Look closely at the parts and it will all become clear.
Calibration test
T4MiniTestSocket.stl contains a cut-down socket you can use for testing the fit of your arms before committing to the full Body print.
A quick word about scaling
According to Wikipedia apparently "there is no scale information [in STL files], and the units are arbitrary". There is often confusion with STL files and metric versus imperial (inches) units. I designed these parts in Sketchup using metric units and they import correctly into my slicer (which is also set to metric). If you have issues, check your application to see if has a way to select metric or alternatively scale down by a factor of 25.4.
Also, the Sketchup file contents are scaled up by 1000 (attempt to solve some Sketchup quirks). I scale each component down by 0.001 before exporting the STL so they are in real millimetre sizes.

• 4 arms (9 grams, 0.5 hour print each*)
  • 1 body (40 grams, 2.75 hour print*)
  • 1 top plate (12 grams, 1 hour print*)
  • 1 bottom tray (14 grams, 1 hour print*)
  • 1 battery pin (almost nothing, real fast)
  • 2 posts (optional)
  • 1 post plate (optional)
    *times were recorded on my Makergear M2 printer which has a 0.35mm nozzle and was printing at 4500mm/min.
    ...and "hardware"...
  • 2,5mm (wide) zip ties (approx 100mm long)
  • some foam for padding the battery compartments. I ended up using self adhesive window draft-stop tape from my local DIY store.
  • some Kyosho Zeal Gel or similar anti-vibration gel and rubber bands for mounting the flight controller and camera.
  • double sided adhesive foam tape (for mounting other electronics)
  • soldering gear and connectors to suit your electrical bits
    ...and stuff to make it fly...
  • I pinched most of the gear from one of these ARF kits ...the quality is a bit average but it flies.
  • UPDATE: 12amp Afro ESCs (SimonK firmware) made a big improvement.
  • UPDATE: I'm now running Lumenier 2206-11 motors and Gemfan 5x3 propellers.
  • I added a KK2 flight controller (because I had an old one lying around). There are probably better options but I haven't investigated yet.
  • You'll also need a Radio control receiver (and transmitter) (eg a Taranis) The X8R receiver really is too big for this size model but it was all I had here so that's what I used.
    • If your new to RC copters then the ArduCopter wiki is a great place to find out everything you need know.

comments.text: Bonehead question, there seems to be a assortment of arms in different sizes?  which should I print.
comments.author: KTMDirtFace

comments.text: Good question :).  The number in mm is the size of the "cup" that holds the motor so measure the size of your motor and then add a couple of millimetres for clearance (eg. for 28mm diameter motor use 30mm cup).  Unless mentioned otherwise the arms are long enough to fit 6 inch propellers (7 inch options are named as such).

comments.text: Hi, could you share with us your PID tuning?
comments.author: Ganollum

comments.text: For what flight controller, firmware version, motors, propellers, ESC combination?  They will all affect the PIDs you need.  Your best bet would be to follow the instructions available for your flight controller for PID tuning.  They may well make special mention about different starting PIDs for small or mini quads as they tend to have lower values (in most firmware) than bigger quads.  The defaults in most firmwares are conservative and should still be an okay starting point.
comments.author: Ganollum

comments.text: No worries.  The T4 mini designs are actually X configurations.  Although the arms are on different angles, the motors all end up  symmetrical and equidistant from the centre of gravity.  The body is effectively just "moved forward" - the front section is taken up with the front arm sockets and the main weight (battery) is in the COG.

comments.text:
Yeah the Multistar ESCs are a little disappointing too - and really difficult to update the firmware (requires soldering to legs on a very small SMD package).
I like this Mini T4 design so I think it's worth trying to find some better hardware. I'm open to recommendations if anyone knows of some good mini motors in stock (and that can ship to New Zealand).
comments.author: Geoffro

comments.text:
Just snagged this new Motor/ESC/Prop kit from RCTimer:
http://www.rctimer.com/product_1136.htmlhttp://www.rctimer.com/product...
So far so good! Great looking motors and CF props! A little cramped in the ESC compartment but it does eventually all fit. I soldered the 2mm plugs directly onto the ESC to avoid extra wire, but this made the ESC's a bit longer and harder to move. May have contributed to the cramped fit.
Running it on 3S but it is supposed to be fine with 4S as well. Just gotta find a 4S that fits in the battery compartment, or design one a bit bigger.
I'll send pictures once I'm happy with the setup, but hovers just over 1/3 throttle with a Naze32, FrSky D4R-II and Mobius all mounted. Very snappy response so far, so it might be a perfect FPV racer!
FYI, I had tried the (pricey) MT1306-3100kV motors with Plush 6A ESC's running BLheli. Naze32 as well, and it was not a great flyer. Lots of wobble that appeared to be from vibration. Had it fall out of the sky a few times with RCTimer 6A ESC's w/SimonK when an ESC would reboot on one motor, even after replacing it 2 times. I think it was going overcurrent, or the MT1306's are rated too close to their max. Overall, not impressed with the combo, and for the price of 2 x MT1306's the RCTimer combo is a much better value.
comments.author: Brendan22

comments.text: Thanks for posting this, the RCTimer kit looks like a good one.

There are some awesome motors that size but they put the housing underneath, ie if I were try and use them in this mini quad I would have to lose the motor pods and go for a flat surface.

Mircoscope mount for my simple usb microscope.
The original mount from the microscope was not accurate to justify, so i decide to use a worm for adjusting. I was inspired from this microscope hack:
http://www.hackerspace-ffm.de/wiki/index.php?title=DIY_Mikroskop 10x and 60x magnify works great from the microscope.
the 200x magnifiy is a little bit unstable. i think there have to be a stepper motor version.

For the assembly you need follow hardware: 2 x 8mm about 30cm stheel shaft
1 x M10 about 30cm thread bar
2 x LM8UU linear bearing
3 x M10 nut
2 x M3 20mm
2 x M3 nut Insert one M10 Nut into the microscope mount and one M10 nut into the gear.
Mount the a m10 nut on the other side of the gear, the thread bar should be have a permant connection with the gear.
Insert the linear bearing into the microscope mount and screw the thread bar trough the m10 nut.
assembly the bottom and top plastic with a small hammer.

This is a design for a piece that fits over the lamp in the lid of a 30 liter BiOrb fish tank (probably fits on other BiOrb tanks too). I made it to make the tank slightly less bright hoping that helps stint the growth of the algae somewhat, and it looks nicer too! For more information about the project go to: http://www.macouno.com/2012/09/14/creating-a-cut-out-for-the-biorb/
Print the object, then clean it a bit with a knife. Then fit it on the lamp of the BiOrb, and if you want you can use one or two tie-wraps to fasten it (not needed but more secure).

description.text: just need some 1/16" steel cable adjust the length as needed for amount of vibration you trying to dampen

comments.text: Yeah, this won't work - it rather enhances the motion, because without any damping it wobbles and because of the weight center shift, it now also tilts forth and back, causing much worse recordings then before.
comments.author: Kulitorum

comments.text:
It's not about motion, it's about high frequency vibration. The cable needs to be stiff enough to not wobble.
I've seen other cable designs like this and they seem to work quite well.
For example the Flite Test crew has this in their shop: http://shop.flitetest.com/multirotors/original-tricopter-camera-mount/http://shop.flitetest.com/mult...
Perhaps it works better because the weight of the battery dampens it more, but the shifting of mass should be even worse.

I put this as a derivative even though I made it from scratch, I made it because I liked the Ultimaker idea but I needed for much wider labels (some of my labels are up to 80mm wide) and I felt it did not need to be as deep and such as theirs, I also added a ledge on the back for clamping it to the table with a spring clamp, you could also drill a few holes and bolt it down. I use a Primera LX400 label printer and make several sizes of product labels on a regular basis. This unit will work with up to 88mm wide labels. I kept printing in mind and it will print without support. My printer did it with near zero cleanup, only a 2 tiny strings from the bridge that were easily removed. P.S. this thing shows errors that Netfabb won't fix but Slic3r had no problem slicing it so any slicer should be OK 2/9/2015 Added 12cm wide version by request.
I printed with 3 perimeters, 3 top / bottom layers and 10% infill at 60mms with .25mm layer height .35mm nozzle

This are two small adaptor pieces to put on the Ramps 1.4 board on your Orca printer.

The board itself is not fixed by screws, it holds just by pushing it into the frame. the board holds very good, it can not fall of by mistake !

author: norcoscia

description.text:
I designed it to be printed in transparent PLA, monolayer, about 8 cm wide, then you can put a Tillandsia inside as tentacles and fix it to lamps/ceiling with nylon wire.  
It prited well.

Print it as a single wall, spiralized, no infill, open top and bottom shape, with transparent or transparent/colored PLA. Then buy a small Tillandsia like this one: http://img139.imageshack.us/img139/8257/jnsy2.jpg Fix it, through ceiling holes, with a rubber band. Tillandsiae grow even upside down, and need just rare water spray to stay alive. Read about them, if you do this, and please post a picture!

title: Fertility Rate in U.S. by Year

description.text: This is my first shot at taking existing data sets and turning them into physical objects. A colleague of mine gave me a basic line graph and I used Sketchup to turn it on it's side and do a 360 degree extrusion. Ends up looking a bit like a chess piece.
I didn't use any support material but you may want to include support due to the fairly large overhang near the bottom of the model. I printed this on a Replicator with the default settings.

comments.text: What is the source of this data? If you give me the years this covers then I can try to add some text to it in TinkerCad and post it as a derivative.Â

Sorry for the lack of information, this was more a test to see that we could take a graph and make it a 3D object. We'll do a better job of documenting along the way next time. :)

I have a drain in the shower very difficult to remove by hand (I hurt my fingers several times wanting to remove it).
So I propose a drain extractor to help you.
You can see that the yellow part is repaired, it is because I printed it in a bad position. I correct the STL position in file that I uploaded. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zix0taJY7yQ&index=3&list=UUzjQ0_Glvzuqm2QkXoZKMqw

The yellow part is symmetric.
For easier to put the screws, you will need to re-drill a bit to the side where the screw come in first
You'll need 2 wood screw with a length between 25 an 30mm

title: KK2.0 Mount for BAH mini Quad

description.text:
This is a mount for the KK2.0 board on a BAH mini quad ( inside ), could possibly work on other mini quads frames as well but haven't tried yet.  I have used double side tape to stick the mount to the frame and small self tappers to fix the board to the plastic mount. I have uploaded the SketchUp file if any one wants to make any changes.  
Version 2 has holes for cable ties and a gap at the back for any wires that might need to get through. Also only 8mm high and not 10mm like Version 1.

Printed on a MakerBot Rep1 with ABS.  0.2 mm, 30 % infill and 1 shell. Will have to use double sided tape to stick KK board on to plastic or drill small holes and use self tapping screws. Then double side tape to stick mount onto frame. Alternatively the SketchUp file could be changed to take cable ties ( maybe the next version)
